intro: Serapias gracilis, commonly known as the slender sandwort, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It belongs to the family Rockcress (Capparaceae) and is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit. The plant produces showy, yellow-orange flowers with five petals, typically blooming in early spring. Its leaves are linear and covered in fine hairs, adapted to thrive in dry, sandy soils. Serapias gracilis is often found in coastal dunes and rocky habitats, showcasing its resilience to harsh environmental conditions.
